abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated as satisfactory,
            with likely sustainability, though only modest institutional
            development impacts. Lessons point at the importance of
            strong, stable relationships between the Bank, and Borrower,
            a problem issue which in this case, can be attributed to
            early changes in the implementing unit's leadership, as
            well as shifting government priorities. Likewise, successive
            changes in Bank supervision leadership, also meant forging
            new relationships, and accommodating to management styles,
            endangering project success, which could have adversely
            impacted project outcomes, despite a sound project
            preparation. Additionally, while the project included
            relevant indicators, it did not incorporate easy to measure
            key performance indicators, that could have guided the
            decision-making process during implementation, and, this
            factor highlights in turn the need to have in place a good
            project management information system, prior to project
            effectiveness. Moreover, Bank supervision teams should
            include members with sectoral experience, in water supply
            and sanitation projects in this case, a coordination that
            would have ensured not only the quality of infrastructure
            investments, but enhanced supervision as well. It is finally
            suggested that focusing on a few, strategic municipalities
            for institutional development, may be the approach for
            including such objectives in municipal development funds
            projects, as well as the use of matching grants, as opposed
            to loans.
